statement: A. CMEtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputLet's denotecorrect match equation(we will denote it as CME) an equation $$$a + b = c$$$ there all integers $$$a$$$, $$$b$$$ and $$$c$$$ are greater than zero.For example, equations $$$2 + 2 = 4$$$ (||+||=||||) and $$$1 + 2 = 3$$$ (|+||=|||) are CME but equations $$$1 + 2 = 4$$$ (|+||=||||), $$$2 + 2 = 3$$$ (||+||=|||), and $$$0 + 1 = 1$$$ (+|=|) are not.Now, you have $$$n$$$ matches. You want to assemble a CME usingallyour matches. Unfortunately, it is possible that you can't assemble the CME using all matches. But you can buy some extra matches and then assemble CME!For example, if $$$n = 2$$$, you can buy two matches and assemble|+|=||, and if $$$n = 5$$$ you can buy one match and assemble||+|=|||.Calculate the minimum number of matches which you have to buy for assembling CME.Note, that you have to answer $$$q$$$ independent queries.InputThe first line contains one integer $$$q$$$ ($$$1 \\le q \\le 100$$$) — the number of queries.The only line of each query contains one integer $$$n$$$ ($$$2 \\le n \\le 10^9$$$) — the number of matches.OutputFor each test case print one integer in single line — the minimum number of matches which you have to buy for assembling CME.ExampleInput4 2 5 8 11Output2 1 0 1NoteThe first and second queries are explained in the statement.In the third query, you can assemble $$$1 + 3 = 4$$$ (|+|||=||||) without buying matches.In the fourth query, buy one match and assemble $$$2 + 4 = 6$$$ (||+||||=||||||).

You are given a number of matches, *n*.  You want to arrange these matches to form a correct match equation (CME), which is an equation of the form $a + b = c$ where *a*, *b*, and *c* are all positive integers.

You may buy additional matches if needed.

For each test case, find the minimum number of extra matches you need to buy to form a CME. 


Input:

The first line contains the number of test cases, *q*.

Each test case contains a single line with an integer *n*, the number of matches you start with.

Output:

For each test case, print the minimum number of extra matches needed to form a CME.

You are given a number of items. You need to arrange them into a specific three-item group.  You can buy more items if needed. Find the minimum number of extra items you need to buy to make the group.
